metadata.description: Semantic concept-to-source mapping for SF permitting knowledge base. Maps ~60 key concepts to their authoritative sources across all structured JSON files, enabling accurate cross-cutting search.
metadata.purpose: When a query mentions a concept (or any of its aliases), this index tells the system exactly which files and JSON paths contain the authoritative answer. Eliminates the 'which file do I search?' problem.
metadata.usage: 1. Tokenize user query. 2. Match tokens against concept aliases. 3. Retrieve all authoritative_sources for matched concepts. 4. Load those specific JSON paths. 5. Synthesize answer.

otc_review.description: Projects eligible for same-day or rapid review at the DBI counter, without entering the in-house review queue.

authoritative_sources.role: 12 project types eligible for OTC without plans
24 project types eligible for OTC with plans
19 project types that are NOT OTC
The one-hour rule and routing criterion
Step 3: OTC vs In-House decision logic

inhouse_review.description: Projects that require detailed multi-station review by DBI staff, taking weeks to months rather than same-day OTC.

one_hour_rule.description: The informal but critical criterion: if a plan reviewer estimates they can review the project in roughly 1 hour per station, it stays OTC. Otherwise it goes to in-house.

authoritative_sources.role: Formal statement of the one-hour rule
What happens when OTC converts to in-house

one_hour_rule.ask_amy: Is the one-hour rule actually enforced consistently? How do plan reviewers estimate?

permit_forms.description: The 7 main DBI permit application forms (Forms 1-8, no Form 6) plus special applications, green building forms, and disabled access forms.

authoritative_sources.role: Decision logic for which form to use

agency_routing.description: Which of the 9+ city agencies must review a permit application, based on project type, scope, and location.

aliases: how much does a permit cost
fee_calculation.description: How DBI calculates permit fees based on construction valuation, project type, and applicable fee tables.

authoritative_sources.role: Building permit fees by valuation tier (10 tiers, 3 categories)
Other permit and plan review fees (hourly, back check, premium)
Standard hourly rates ($481 plan review, $571 inspection)
Electrical permit fees (5 categories with sub-tiers)

construction_valuation.description: The declared construction cost that determines permit fees. DBI uses ICC methodology and may adjust declared values.

planning_review.description: San Francisco Planning Department review of building permits for zoning compliance, use authorization, and environmental review.

section_311.description: The 30-day public notification requirement for projects that exceed certain thresholds (building expansion, new construction, demolition). Neighbors can file DR requests.

authoritative_sources.role: Full Section 311/312 rules, thresholds, exempt projects, DR process

section_311.ask_amy: How often does the 30 days actually turn into a DR request? What percentage — 5%? 20%?

conditional_use.description: Projects requiring Planning Commission approval because the use is conditionally (not principally) permitted in the zoning district.
conditional_use.ask_amy: When a project needs a CU hearing, what's the realistic calendar wait? The code says 90 days — is that real?

section_309.description: Planning Commission review required for projects in C-3 (downtown) districts that need exceptions from code standards.

historic_preservation.description: Review required for projects affecting designated landmarks, historic districts (Article 10), or downtown conservation districts (Article 11).

authoritative_sources.role: Full Article 10/11 review process, COA requirements, demolition standards

ceqa.description: California Environmental Quality Act review, required for projects needing CU authorization, variances, or Section 309/329 review.

authoritative_sources.role: When CEQA is required, categorical exemptions, timeline implications

fire_department.description: Fire Department plan review for projects involving assembly occupancy, high-rise buildings, sprinkler/alarm systems, commercial kitchens, and changes in occupancy classification.

sprinkler_required.description: When automatic fire sprinkler systems are required — by occupancy type, building height, occupant load, or existing building retrofit mandates.

authoritative_sources.role: Complete sprinkler trigger rules by occupancy/height/use
Retrofit requirements for SRO, hotels, high-rise

fire_alarm.description: When fire alarm systems are required, including the $99K construction cost threshold that triggers sleeping area alarm upgrades in existing buildings.

authoritative_sources.role: Complete fire alarm trigger rules, R-2 thresholds, certification

assembly_occupancy.description: Assembly occupancy classification and the occupant load thresholds that trigger sprinkler, fire alarm, and SFFD review requirements.

authoritative_sources.role: Sprinkler thresholds: A-2 at 100 occupants / 5000 sqft, general A at 300 / 12000

high_rise.description: Requirements for buildings with occupied floors >75ft above lowest fire department access. Tiered at 75ft, 120ft, and 240ft.

authoritative_sources.role: Tiered requirements at 75ft/120ft, new vs existing
Fire command center, ERRCS, air replenishment

commercial_kitchen_hood.canonical_name: Commercial Kitchen Hood / Type I Hood
commercial_kitchen_hood.description: Automatic fire-extinguishing systems required for commercial cooking equipment producing grease-laden vapors. Service required every 6 months.

authoritative_sources.role: Complete hood system requirements, servicing, personnel

restaurant.description: Converting a space to restaurant use — involves change-of-use, commercial kitchen, Type I hood, assembly occupancy, DPH, SFFD, and potentially Planning review.

authoritative_sources.role: CU triggers for formula retail, late-night

adu.description: ADU construction or legalization — NOT OTC, but exempt from Section 311 notification and many historic review requirements.

authoritative_sources.role: ADU explicitly listed as NOT OTC

change_of_use.canonical_name: Change of Use / Occupancy Classification Change
change_of_use.description: Changing the occupancy classification of a building or space (e.g., retail→restaurant, office→residential). Triggers Planning review, potentially CU, and SFFD if assembly.

authoritative_sources.role: When change of use requires CU
Change of occupancy classification triggers SFFD
G-20 routing for change-of-use project types

commercial_ti.description: Interior build-out of commercial/office space — often OTC-eligible but can be bumped to in-house by C-3 zoning or scope.

seismic.description: Seismic retrofit requirements including mandatory soft-story retrofit (AB-094/106), URM retrofit (Table 1A-S), and voluntary programs.

authoritative_sources.role: Mandatory concrete building seismic program (newest, July 2025)

priority_processing.description: Expedited permit processing for eligible project types: emergency, ADA, clean energy, seismic, housing, ADU.

authoritative_sources.role: AB-004 index entry with line range

site_permit.description: An iterative permitting pathway for large/complex projects, allowing phased construction with 4+ payment stages.

authoritative_sources.role: AB-032 index entry with line range

completeness_checklist.description: The 13-section checklist that DBI uses to determine if a permit application is complete enough to enter review.

authoritative_sources.role: 13 checklist sections with all required items

completeness_checklist.ask_amy: What are the top 3 specific items that cause rejections?

required_documents.description: Universal and conditional document requirements for permit applications.

aliases: when will I get my permit
timeline.description: Estimated timeframes for different permit pathways. OTC: same day. In-house: 4-16+ weeks. CU: 3+ months.

authoritative_sources.role: In-house review process steps with approximate timeframes

timeline.ask_amy: What's the real timeline for a typical residential alteration from application to approved permit?

public_health.description: DPH review triggered by food preparation facilities, cannabis operations, and Maher Ordinance environmental contamination sites.

authoritative_sources.role: DPH triggers: food facilities, cannabis, Maher/Article 31

disability_access.description: ADA and California accessibility requirements for commercial and public accommodations, including path-of-travel triggers.

sfpuc.description: San Francisco Public Utilities Commission review for water service connections, sewer capacity, and stormwater management (triggered at 5,000+ sq ft impervious surface).

authoritative_sources.role: PUC triggers: water service, stormwater 5000+ sqft
Stormwater pre-application requirement and 40,000 sqft water reuse trigger

green_building.description: San Francisco green building requirements per AB-093, GS form selection logic, Title 24 energy compliance, rating system pathways (LEED/GreenPoint Rated), compliance methods, and the all-electric new construction mandate (AB-112).

authoritative_sources.role: GS-1 through GS-6 form selection decision tree (5 steps)
Which rating system (LEED/GreenPoint/Locally Required) applies by occupancy and size
Professional qualifications, exemptions for small residential
Title 24 Part 6 in green building context, AB-112 all-electric mandate
ADU, historic, mixed occupancy, demolition replacement, large commercial TI
9 common scenarios with form, rating system, and professional requirements
Attachment E final compliance, TCO rules, quality assurance
Detailed Title 24 Part 6 energy forms and compliance documentation

solar.description: Solar PV, battery storage, and EV charging permits — often eligible for AB-004 priority processing.

authoritative_sources.role: Electrical fees for solar PV installations

demolition.description: Demolition of existing structures — requires Form 6, asbestos survey, BAAQMD notification, and potentially Section 317 CU review for residential.

penalty_fees.description: Penalties for work done without permits: 9x the permit issuance fee plus the original fee. Legalization processes.

authoritative_sources.role: Penalty fees: 9x permit issuance + original, vacant building registration

school_impact_fee.description: SFUSD fees calculated by DBI based on new commercial floor area. Must be paid PRIOR to permit issuance.

authoritative_sources.role: School Impact Fee: commercial floor area increase, references G-11

structural_review.description: Structural design review and peer review requirements, especially for tall buildings and complex seismic designs.

special_inspections.description: When special inspections are required during construction — structural work, smoke control, sprinkler systems.

authoritative_sources.role: AB-047: Smoke control submittal criteria (866 lines)

adaptive_reuse.description: Converting commercial/office buildings to residential use — detailed guidelines in G-29.

authoritative_sources.role: G-29 full text (34K chars) — misplaced in S-series due to naming offset

facade_inspection.description: Mandatory facade inspection program for buildings 6+ stories — periodic inspection and maintenance requirements.

local_equivalency.description: Procedure for approving local equivalencies — alternative methods or materials that meet code intent without literal compliance.

permit_consultant.description: Registered land use consultants who navigate the DBI process on behalf of clients.

authoritative_sources.role: Amy Lee profile: 3S LLC, rank #42, 117 DBI permits

ocii.canonical_name: OCII (Office of Community Investment and Infrastructure)
ocii.description: OCII routes INSTEAD of Planning in designated redevelopment areas (Mission Bay, Hunters Point, Treasure Island, etc.).

authoritative_sources.role: G-20 OCII routing (replaces Planning in OCII areas)

dpw_streets.canonical_name: DPW / Bureau of Street-Use and Mapping
dpw_streets.description: DPW review for projects affecting the public right-of-way — curb cuts, sidewalk work, parklets, street-space permits.

authoritative_sources.role: BSM triggers: right-of-way entry/exit, curb cuts

back_check.description: The re-review process after DBI issues comments on submitted plans. Up to 3 rounds before escalation.

authoritative_sources.role: Back check fees (first back check included, subsequent hourly)
Back check process within in-house review

premium_review.description: Paid expedited plan review service — 50% surcharge plus $1,000 flat fee on top of standard plan review fees.

pre_application.description: Optional or required pre-application meeting with DBI/agencies before formal submission. $368/hr, minimum 4 hours for complex projects.

refund.description: Refund policies for permit fees — $357 minimum processing fee deducted, no refund after work starts.

authoritative_sources.role: Refund policies: amount paid less $357, no refund after work starts

formula_retail.description: Special Planning review required for retail/restaurant businesses that are part of chains with 11+ locations worldwide.

window_replacement.description: Window replacement permits — OTC-eligible for standard replacement, but complicated by historic district requirements.

authoritative_sources.role: Historic districts require COA for exterior changes including windows

kitchen_remodel.description: Kitchen remodel permits — OTC if layout-changing (with plans), may trigger plumbing/electrical sub-permits for moved fixtures.

authoritative_sources.role: Layout-changing remodels are OTC with plans
In-kind kitchen/bath replacement is OTC without plans

residential_remodel.description: Broad category of residential renovation work — routing depends on scope (OTC for simple, in-house for structural/unit changes).

authoritative_sources.role: Residential projects requiring in-house (ADU, unit changes, etc.)

electronic_plan_review.description: Since January 1, 2024, DBI requires 100% electronic plan review through Bluebeam Studio. All plans must be submitted as PDF.
electronic_plan_review.ask_amy: Has the shift to 100% EPR changed anything about how you prepare submissions?

permit_expiration.description: Complete permit expiration rules per SFBC Section 106A. Table A governs application expiration by valuation (360/720 days). Table B governs work completion deadlines by valuation ($1-$100K: 360 days, $100K-$2.5M: 1,080 days, $2.5M+: 1,440 days). Demolition permits: 180 days. Extensions available with written request + fee. Expired permits require new applications (106A.4.4.1) or alteration permits (106A.4.4.2).

authoritative_sources.role: Table B: work completion deadlines by valuation tier (360/1,080/1,440 days)
Table A: application expiration by valuation (360/720 days)
106A.4.4.1: new application required for expired permits
107A.6: fee refund rules for expired/abandoned permits

permit_requirements.description: Section 106A.1 lists 19 work types requiring permits (solar, EV, gas ban, ADU, demolition, grading, signs, boilers, change of occupancy, etc.). Section 106A.2 lists 26 categories of work exempt from permit (small accessory buildings, fences, painting, reroofing under 25%, door replacement, etc.). Exemptions do not authorize code violations.

authoritative_sources.role: 19 work types requiring permits under Section 106A.1
26 categories of exempt work under Section 106A.2
Application requirements and unauthorized dwelling unit legalization
OTC eligibility criteria for specific project types

inspections.description: Full inspections chapter (Section 108A). Nine required inspection stages: general/structural framework, foundation, concrete slab/under-floor, reinforcing steel, structural steel, frame, lath/gypsum board, fire-rated suspended ceilings, and final inspection. First reinspection is free; subsequent reinspections are charged. Off-hours inspections available by arrangement.

authoritative_sources.role: 9 required inspection stages with timing and requirements

certificates_of_occupancy.description: Section 109A: No building may be used or occupied until the Building Official issues a certificate. Temporary certificates valid for up to 12 months. Apartment house/hotel licenses required for all R-1 and R-2 occupancies. Amended certificates track dwelling unit count changes.

authoritative_sources.role: No building may be used until certificate is issued
Apartment house and hotel license fees

enforcement.description: Full enforcement pipeline: Inspection → NOV (within 15 days) → Administrative Hearing (within 60 days) → Administrative Order (180-day compliance, one 90-day extension). Emergency orders bypass hearings for imminent hazards (48-hour compliance). Civil penalties $200-$1,000/day per violation per unit. Work-without-permit investigation fees per Table 1A-K, appealable but never below 2x permit fee.

appeals_bodies.canonical_name: Appeals Bodies — Board of Examiners, Abatement Appeals, Access Appeals
appeals_bodies.description: Three main appeals bodies: Board of Examiners (13 members, materials/methods/variances), Abatement Appeals Board (7 members = Building Inspection Commission, enforcement order appeals), Access Appeals Commission (5 members, disability access). Also covers vacant building registration (103A.4) and vacant commercial storefront registration (103A.5).

authoritative_sources.role: 13-member board: new materials, variances, code interpretations
Enforcement appeals, financial hardship moratorium, displacement moratorium
Disability access equivalent facilitation, technical infeasibility, hardship
103A.5: Annual registration for vacant commercial storefronts

noise_insulation.description: Acoustical insulation requirements for residential construction, particularly near transit corridors.

authoritative_sources.role: Acoustical report requirement for new residential

hotel_conversion.description: San Francisco hotel conversion ordinance — annual reporting, conversion permits, and fee schedules.

authoritative_sources.role: Residential code enforcement and license fees for apartment/hotel

construction_waste.description: Construction waste management requirements — triggered by new construction, commercial additions 1000+ sqft, or remodels $200K+.

condo_conversion.description: Converting rental units or TICs to condominiums — requires survey, plumbing/mechanical inspection, and specific fees.

e_bike_charging.description: New 2024 requirement: 5+ powered mobility devices charging indoors triggers sprinkler and fire alarm requirements.

controller_bond.description: Controller review and labor compliance bond required for multi-residential projects with 10+ housing units.

plan_signature_requirements.description: Defines 4 categories of who must sign plans: Exempt (unlicensed OK), Licensed Contractor, Registered Engineer/Architect, Special Status. Based on project scope, occupancy, construction type, span, and valuation.

authoritative_sources.role: 9 exempt conditions — unlicensed persons may sign
7 triggers requiring CA-licensed architect or engineer
How to affix signature, seal, and stamp on plans

restaurant_permit_guide.description: Comprehensive guide for restaurant building permits — covers DBI, Planning, DPH, SFFD coordination, 8-step process, occupancy classification (Group B vs A-2), fees, and common issues.

authoritative_sources.role: Group B (≤50) vs Group A-2 (>50) classification
All permits needed — building, plumbing, electrical, DPH, SFFD
DPH construction standards for food facilities

seismic_accessibility.canonical_name: Seismic Path of Travel / Mixed-Use Accessibility (DA-12)
seismic_accessibility.description: When a seismic retrofit triggers accessibility obligations in mixed-use buildings. Only the commercial portion triggers Chapter 11B. Adjusted cost = (% commercial floor area) × total construction cost, then apply 20% rule.

authoritative_sources.role: Full DA-12 encoding with adjusted cost formula, scope determination, and worked example

change_of_use_accessibility.canonical_name: Change of Use Path of Travel (DA-13)
change_of_use_accessibility.description: Change of use = alteration for accessibility. Entire changed-use area must comply with CBC 11B. Paperwork-only COU with $1 permit → 20% of $1 = negligible. Exception #2 lists 5 priority path-of-travel elements.

authoritative_sources.role: Full DA-13 encoding with cost determination, Exception #2, and COU-without-construction rule

earthquake_brace_bolt.description: EBB incentive program for pre-1979 wood-frame homes with cripple walls ≤4ft. Up to $3K reimbursement. OTC-eligible if prescriptive per CEBC Appendix A3. No licensed professional required for prescriptive design (G-01 Status I).

authoritative_sources.role: OTC review path, Form 8, no licensed professional for prescriptive
Required plan elements and CEBC A3 references
Standard retrofit scope and out-of-scope items
